items.title: Choice-case validation is not applied
nested lists within container don't allow for leaf add
No support for two primary keys in a list
JSON IETF serialization not using namespace prefix (fails IETF deserialization)
items.body:
I'm generating OpenConfig wifi python code with pyang like this...

```
$ pyang --plugindir /Users/mark/go/src/github.com/mistsys/demoapi/venv/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pyangbind/plugin -f pybind --path /tmp/openconfig_public/release/models --build-notifications -o /Users/mark/go/src/github.com/mistsys/demoapi/demoapi/openconfig/models/openconfig_access_points.py /tmp/openconfig_public/release/models/wifi/access-points/openconfig-access-points.yang
```

For any property of a 'openconfig-wifi-type' (ie: 'FREQ_2GHZ'), the generated restrictions use the yang 'oc-wifi-prefix' located in 'openconfig-wifi-types' (looks good to me).

However, when using `pybindJSON.dumps` to serialize in `ietf` mode, the generated JSON uses the defining module as the namespace (ie: `openconfig-wifi-types:FREQ_2GHZ`) rather than the yang model prefix (ie: `oc-wifi-types:FREQ_2GH`)...

```
$ aps = openconfig_access_points()
$ oc_ap = aps.access_points.access_point.add(hostname)
$ radio = oc_ap.radios.radio.add(0)
$ radio.config.operating_frequency = 'FREQ_5GHZ'
$ pybindJSON.dumps(oc_aps, mode='ietf', indent=None)
```

The net result is that I'm seeing an error when deserializing the JSON IETF string that was generated with `pybindJSON.dumps`...

```
            # deserialize the json-ietf data
            aps = openconfig_access_points()
            d = json.loads(json_ietf)
            pybindJSONDecoder.load_ietf_json(d, None, None, obj=aps)
```

Here is the error where the `openconfig-wifi-types:FREQ_2GHZ` type is not within the restricted list generated by pyang (ie: needs to be `oc-wifi-types:FREQ_2GHZ` using the `oc-wifi-type` namespace prefix)...

```
  File "/Users/mark/go/src/github.com/mistsys/demoapi/demoapi/openconfig/models/openconfig_access_points.py", line 152, in _set_operating_frequency
    'generated-type': """YANGDynClass(base=RestrictedClassType(base_type=six.text_type, restriction_type="dict_key", restriction_arg={u'oc-wifi-types:FREQ_2GHZ': {u'@namespace': u'http://openconfig.net/yang/wifi/types', u'@module': u'openconfig-wifi-types'}, u'oc-wifi-types:FREQ_5GHZ': {u'@namespace': u'http://openconfig.net/yang/wifi/types', u'@module': u'openconfig-wifi-types'}, u'oc-wifi-types:FREQ_2_5_GHZ': {u'@namespace': u'http://openconfig.net/yang/wifi/types', u'@module': u'openconfig-wifi-types'}, u'FREQ_5GHZ': {u'@namespace': u'http://openconfig.net/yang/wifi/types', u'@module': u'openconfig-wifi-types'}, u'FREQ_2_5_GHZ': {u'@namespace': u'http://openconfig.net/yang/wifi/types', u'@module': u'openconfig-wifi-types'}, u'FREQ_2GHZ': {u'@namespace': u'http://openconfig.net/yang/wifi/types', u'@module': u'openconfig-wifi-types'}},), is_leaf=True, yang_name="operating-frequency", parent=self, path_helper=self._path_helper, extmethods=self._extmethods, register_paths=True, namespace='http://openconfig.net/yang/wifi/access-points', defining_module='openconfig-access-points', yang_type='identityref', is_config=True)""",
ValueError: {'error-string': 'operating_frequency must be of a type compatible with identityref', 'generated-type': 'YANGDynClass(base=RestrictedClassType(base_type=six.text_type, restriction_type="dict_key", restriction_arg={u\'oc-wifi-types:FREQ_2GHZ\': {u\'@namespace\': u\'http://openconfig.net/yang/wifi/types\', u\'@module\': u\'openconfig-wifi-types\'}, u\'oc-wifi-types:FREQ_5GHZ\': {u\'@namespace\': u\'http://openconfig.net/yang/wifi/types\', u\'@module\': u\'openconfig-wifi-types\'}, u\'oc-wifi-types:FREQ_2_5_GHZ\': {u\'@namespace\': u\'http://openconfig.net/yang/wifi/types\', u\'@module\': u\'openconfig-wifi-types\'}, u\'FREQ_5GHZ\': {u\'@namespace\': u\'http://openconfig.net/yang/wifi/types\', u\'@module\': u\'openconfig-wifi-types\'}, u\'FREQ_2_5_GHZ\': {u\'@namespace\': u\'http://openconfig.net/yang/wifi/types\', u\'@module\': u\'openconfig-wifi-types\'}, u\'FREQ_2GHZ\': {u\'@namespace\': u\'http://openconfig.net/yang/wifi/types\', u\'@module\': u\'openconfig-wifi-types\'}},), is_leaf=True, yang_name="operating-frequency", parent=self, path_helper=self._path_helper, extmethods=self._extmethods, register_paths=True, namespace=\'http://openconfig.net/yang/wifi/access-points\', defining_module=\'openconfig-access-points\', yang_type=\'identityref\', is_config=True)', 'defined-type': 'openconfig-access-points:identityref'}
```

It seems like this code always uses the defining module rather than the namespace prefix of the type...

https://github.com/robshakir/pyangbind/blob/master/pyangbind/lib/serialise.py#L545-L548

Hopefully, I'm missing something basic, thanks!

items.title: XML support for serialization
items.body:
I can read from the doc that XML is not supported as a serialization format.
[https://github.com/robshakir/pyangbind#serialising-a-data-instance-](https://github.com/robshakir/pyangbind#serialising-a-data-instance-)
--> "XML - the rules for this mapping are defined in RFC 7950 - **currently NOT SUPPORTED**."

Is it foreseen? Is there anyone working on it already or interested in developing it?

Also is it worth it? I have no idea of the ratio of devices supporting XML/JSON today.

Regards,
Roland

items.title: Look into contributions from StackStorm/pyangbind
items.body:
@badaniya has forked this repo to https://github.com/StackStorm/pyangbind and released it as `pyangbind-brcd`. While I haven't had a chance to go through and see specifically what has been added, but there have been 15 releases to PyPi under this name, so I would like to think there are some good juicy bits in there.

At a first glance, it seems that some of these are bugfixes which I have already tackled, but if not then I would certainly like to get some of that work merged up into here and try to deprecate the forked package.

items.title: pyangbind 0.7.0 egg contains all of the test suite
items.body: The egg file for pyangbind 0.7.0 contains the full tests/ directory, which means when installing the egg it will end up in site-directory/tests causing import problems down the road -- e.g. when doing `import tests.foobar from ...`.

items.title: Leaf-list stores multiple duplicate values
items.body:
Hello,
I noticed in [RFC 6020 section 7.7 for leaf-list](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6020#section-7.7) that there is a requirement on leaf-list which we do not follow in pyangbind.

`The values in a leaf-list MUST be unique.`

### Example:
Given the following yang model:
```yang
module test {
    namespace "http://foo/bar/test/1.0";
    prefix test;
    leaf-list my-leaf-list {
        type string;
    }
}
```
#### Expected
```python
>>> from test import test
>>> from pyangbind.lib.xpathhelper import YANGPathHelper
>>>
>>> graph = test(ph=YANGPathHelper())
>>>
>>> graph.my_leaf_list = ['foo', 'foo']
>>> graph.get()
{'my-leaf-list': [u'foo']}
```
#### Actual
```python
>>> graph.get()
{'my-leaf-list': [u'foo', u'foo']}
```

I think the leaf-list structure might need to resemble a set instead of a list, unless I misunderstood the rfc.

items.title: Netconf XML requests using pyangbind Class
items.body:
Hi,

As an experiment, I attempted integrating  ncclient, a python based Netconf client with the pyangbind.
With this on set/get operation of the pyangbind auto-generated class objects, I was able to generate its equivalent edit-config/get Netconf XML messages. 

As you know, the Netconf protocol allows multiple yang objects to be configured with a single edit-config message.The same was taken into consideration. So multiple pyangbind generated yang objects can be set before generating a Netconf edit-config message for them.

My development involved writing a new class called pybindXMLEncoder to generate the XML based Netconf message.The same will be fed to the ncclient APIs to send the required Netconf message.

I also did minor additions to the pybind.py.This was needed to keep track of the list of objects user is setting through set operation before generating the edit-config message.

I feel that this can be useful to the community. if you think this will be of use or if you think you need to know more on the changes I can write to you in mail with details of my changes.

Thanks and regards,
Parameswaran Krishnamurthy

If you set `DEL=true` in `yang_tests.sh`, then the following tests are reported as failing:

- tests/misc
- tests/presence
- submodules

This is because these tests use `unittest.main`, which rejects the `-k` argument used to indicate that the output should not be deleted.

items.title: could not resolve typedefs error
items.body:
Hi,

I faced an issue in compiling the attached yang file acl-example.txt (taken from OpenConfig public release for acl model with modification) using pyangbind with the following error:

[acl-example.txt](https://github.com/robshakir/pyangbind/files/410559/acl-example.txt)

$ pyang --plugindir $PYBINDPLUGIN -f pybind -p $SDIR/ -o $SDIR/binding.py $SDIR/acl-example.yang
could not find a match for acl:ethertype-type type -> [u'uint16', u'identityref']
could not find a match for acl:ip-protocol-type type -> [u'uint8', u'identityref']
could not find a match for ethertype-type type -> [u'uint16', u'identityref']
could not find a match for ip-protocol-type type -> [u'uint8', u'identityref']
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/local/bin/pyang", line 4, in <module>
    **import**('pkg_resources').run_script('pyang==1.7', 'pyang')
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pkg_resources/**init**.py", line 726, in run_script
    self.require(requires)[0].run_script(script_name, ns)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pkg_resources/**init**.py", line 1651, in run_script
    exec(code, namespace, namespace)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pyang-1.7-py2.7.egg/EGG-INFO/scripts/pyang", line 434, in <module>
    run()
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pyang-1.7-py2.7.egg/EGG-INFO/scripts/pyang", line 408, in run
    emit_obj.emit(ctx, modules, fd)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pyangbind-0.5.7-py2.7.egg/pyangbind/plugin/pybind.py", line 211, in emit
    build_pybind(ctx, modules, fd)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pyangbind-0.5.7-py2.7.egg/pyangbind/plugin/pybind.py", line 389, in build_pybind
    build_typedefs(ctx, defn['typedef'])
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pyangbind-0.5.7-py2.7.egg/pyangbind/plugin/pybind.py", line 590, in build_typedefs
    raise TypeError("could not resolve typedefs %s" % error_ids)
TypeError: could not resolve typedefs [u'acl:ethertype-type', u'acl:ip-protocol-type', u'ethertype-type', u'ip-protocol-type']

After simple debugging I found out that these lines were causing the problem, identityref inside a union type, and deleting the identityref works:

  typedef ip-protocol-type {
    type union {
      type uint8 {
        range 0..254;
      }
      type identityref {
        base IP_PROTOCOL;
      }
    }
    description
      "The IP protocol number may be expressed as a valid protocol
      number (integer) or using a protocol type defined by the
      IP_PROTOCOL identity";
  }

The use case for this would be in creating an ACL model with packet matching arbitrary IP protocol number or using predefined string for user readability (such as TCP 6 or UDP 17). I wonder if this is by design or there is a bug in the pyangbind plugin?

Regards,
freeze

items.title: YANG Notifications
items.body:
Hi Rob!

I found in your web page that pyangbind supports YANG RPCs (http://pynms.io/pyangbind/rpc/), but I couldn't found anything about YANG notifications (https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6020#section-4.2.10). Does it has any module dealing with YANG notifications?

In my app I need to issue/receive notifications and will be helpful to have mechanisms to easily generate and parse them in a similar way than that used in RPCs to generate inputs (http://pynms.io/pyangbind/rpc/#exinput) and to parse outputs (http://pynms.io/pyangbind/rpc/#exoutput).

Could it be possible to implement the corresponding structures for that, also reading the models from the YANG files? If you need help testing those functionality, let me know! I can help you on that!

TIA,
Lluis

items.title: Help with RestrictedClassType/YANGBaseClass
items.body:
Hi Rob,

I've got a snippet of code, which takes a generic bindings object, and tries to determine an appropriate SQL Datatype to use for it. The code is roughly based on the JSON Serialiser functionality. Or at least, an older iteration of that code.

The code takes a `PybindBase` decendant, and attempts to map a SQL datatype...

```
    # Key definition
    self.is_key_val = obj._is_keyval

    # Column data type
    if hasattr(obj, "_pybind_base_class"):
    # Special Data Type, could include constraints
    pybind_type = getattr(obj, "_pybind_base_class")
    if pybind_type == "pyangbind.lib.yangtypes.RestrictedClass":
        pybind_type = getattr(obj, "_restricted_class_base")[0]
    else:
    pybind_type = obj.__name__

    if pybind_type in ['int', 'long']:
    self.mapped_type = "Integer"
    # TODO
    # elif pybind_type in ["pyangbind.lib.yangtypes.RestrictedPrecisionDecimal"]:
    #     self.mapped_type = "Float"
    elif pybind_type in ["pyangbind.lib.yangtypes.YANGBool"]:
    self.mapped_type = "Boolean"
    elif pybind_type == "unicode":
    self.mapped_type = "Unicode"
    # TODO
    # elif pybind_type in ["bitarray.bitarray", "lib.yangtypes.ReferencePathType"]:
    #     self.mapped_type = "None" #to-do
    else:
    raise Exception('Unmapped PyangBind Type Encountered: ', pybind_type)
```

This all works fine, and I'm now trying to see if I can improve this to include a maximum column size in the case of restricted values.

Case in point, 

```
leaf registration-id {
  description "The registration-id of the default destination endpoint.";
  type string {
    length "1..67";
  }
}
```

```
self.__registration_id = YANGDynClass(base=RestrictedClassType(base_type=unicode, restriction_dict={'length': [u'1..67']}), is_leaf=True, yang_name="registration-id", parent=self, choice=(u'selection', u'use-endpoint-default-server'), path_helper=self._path_helper, extmethods=self._extmethods, register_paths=True, namespace='http://genband.com/acs', defining_module='acs', yang_type='string', is_config=True)
```

I have a difficult time with the YANGDynClass definitions, and how one can inspect them during run-time. My debugger (PyCharm Community Edition) seems to show me very little when I attempt to inspect these.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/16472288/15103027/9c580234-15fa-11e6-8657-b745a3012a2b.png)

I'm curious what information I might be able to pull out at run-time that might help me, such as the restriction-dict relating to the pybinding element.

I hope this makes sense, 

Thanks,
Mark

As you can see, I've tried to isolate the issue a little bit, but in actual practice my code is running something like:

            acs = yang_acs.acs()

items.title: Yang bits built-in type
Differentiate between empty and boolean nodes
Expose information about field constraints
items.body:
I'm writing some code that's attempting to make automated changes to a Pyangbind object tree (for model-based testing). In order for my code to make valid changes, it needs to know the types of fields, their constraints and which of them are non-configurable status fields. Obviously I can extract this information from the Yang model separately, but it seems a shame that I've already got the Pyangbind object in front of me but I can't query it to find metadata.

One obvious problem is how to expose this. The ideal would be something like:

```
>>> config.users.username.is_config
True
>>> config.users.date_created.is_config
False
```

But if this ends up applied to non-leafs it could get confused with a real Yang member. Perhaps it actually belongs on the type (since it's a property of the type and not the value stored in it), so it would be something like:

```
>>> type(config.users.username).is_config
True
```

items.title: YANGList type with string key containing a space char
items.body:
For a YANG type containing a list which has a String Key, the Add and Get function expects a space delimited key string representation.

For example, a list which has a key of a String Value and an Integer value, the add function might expect:

`somelist.add("somekeystring 1")`

This logic breaks when the String key value contains a space

`somelist.add("some key string 1")`

On another note, is it possible for yangtypes.YANGListType.YANGList.add() to return a pointer to the newly created list object? Rather than the key value?

This shortens the following from

`somelist.add("somekeystring 1")`
`newitem = somelist.get("somekeystring 1")`

to be

`newitem = somelist.add("somekeystring 1")`

Thanks,
Mark

items.title: No support for complex ranges
items.body:
RFC 6020 allows ranges to be discontinuous, using the | to separate each sub-range, as long as the range delimiters increase from left to right. For example the following is allowed:

```
type int8 {
    range "-10 .. -5 | 5 .. 10 | 20 .. 30"
}
```

See section 9.2.4 for details: https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6020#section-9.2.4
This also seems to apply to string lengths: https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6020#section-9.4.4

If such a range exists in an input yang file, the follow error occurs:

```
  File "/home/msuther/Repositories/pyangbind/lib/yangtypes.py", line 839, in YANGDynClass
    return YANGBaseClass(*args, **kwargs)
  File "/home/msuther/Repositories/pyangbind/lib/yangtypes.py", line 717, in __init__
    raise TypeError, "couldn't generate dynamic type -> %s -> %s" % (type(e),e)
TypeError: couldn't generate dynamic type -> <type 'exceptions.ValueError'> -> too many values to unpack
```

items.title: Restrictions on typedefs are not supported

milestone.title: release.00
milestone.description: Features required for an initial public release of pyangbind.

items.body:
No support for cases where a restriction is placed on a typedef - for example (from ietf-inet-types.yang):

``` javascript
  typedef ipv4-address-no-zone {
    type inet:ipv4-address {
      pattern '[0-9\.]*';
    }
    description
      "An IPv4 address without a zone index.  This type, derived from
       ipv4-address, may be used in situations where the zone is
       known from the context and hence no zone index is needed.";
  }
```

In this case, pyangbind will not parse the "pattern" statement. 

RFC6020 states that the following stmts should be supported (but with restrictions to their applicability based on the base type):

```
               +------------------+---------+-------------+
               | substatement     | section | cardinality |
               +------------------+---------+-------------+
               | bit              | 9.7.4   | 0..n        |
               | enum             | 9.6.4   | 0..n        |
               | length           | 9.4.4   | 0..1        |
               | path             | 9.9.2   | 0..1        |
               | pattern          | 9.4.6   | 0..n        |
               | range            | 9.2.4   | 0..1        |
               | require-instance | 9.13.2  | 0..1        |
               | type             | 7.4     | 0..n        |
               +------------------+---------+-------------+
```

It is not clear (and the fix for this issue needs to determine) how restrictions are layered - for example, should a string type with a specified pattern then have another pattern that is applied on top of it?

items.title: config: false is not properly inherited

milestone.title: release.00
milestone.description: Features required for an initial public release of pyangbind.

items.body: When "config: false" is set on a container, the leaves that are contained in it are not marked as config: false. A mechanism for the config state of the parent container to be carried between `get_children()` methods is needed.
